TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was placed in police custody on suspicion of drug trafficking . On DATE ORG ordered that the applicant be detained on remand .

CARDINAL . The court based its detention order on a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offence of drug trafficking and the severity of the likely penalty , which gave rise to a fear that the applicant would obstruct the proceedings . Moreover , the court took into account that other suspects had remained at large , which would pose a risk of collusion if the applicant were released .
CARDINAL . Subsequent decisions on the extension of the applicant 's pre - trial detention were taken on DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . The courts referred to the complexity of the case , the need to conduct further investigations , the probability of collusion between the applicant and other suspects and exertion of unlawful pressure on witnesses by the applicant . They stressed that the fact that the applicant had not pleaded guilty posed an additional risk of his influencing other persons involved in the proceedings . In their opinion no other preventive measure could ensure the proper conduct of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on several occasions against the decisions extending his detention and requested release from detention or the imposition of a more lenient preventive measure , drawing the court 's attention to his poor state of health .
CARDINAL . On DATE a telephone company was requested to provide an itemised bill of the applicant 's telephone calls to other suspects .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE confrontations of witnesses and suspects took place .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor ordered an expert opinion of a heart specialist with a view to establishing the applicant 's state of health . No grounds for the applicant 's release from detention were found .

CARDINAL . On DATE an expert opinion was ordered with a view to determining whether the substance found in the course of police operations had been an illegal drug . The opinion was submitted on CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE expert opinions concerning a weapon which had been found by the police were submitted .
CARDINAL . On DATE another expert opinion of a heart specialist was ordered . Again , the applicant was found to be fit for detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE a bill of indictment against the applicant and CARDINAL other co - accused was lodged with the court . The applicant did not plead guilty .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court decided to transfer the case file to ORG so that shortcomings in the investigation could be corrected .
CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL expert opinions were ordered with a view to establishing the applicant 's mental health .
CARDINAL . On DATE expert opinions on cardiology and diabetology were ordered . The experts did not find any grounds for the applicant 's release .

CARDINAL . On DATE an expert opinion on neurology was submitted . No grounds for the applicant 's release were found , although it was stated in this opinion that his prolonged detention might pose some future risk to his health and he was referred to a prison hospital for observation . The date of his admission to hospital was fixed for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG gave a judgment . The applicant was found guilty of drug trafficking and sentenced to DATE imprisonment . The court ordered that the applicant remain in custody until the prison sentence could be enforced .
